message_1: A college offers 6 elective courses for next semester. A student needs to choose 3 of them for credit. How many ways can a student choose their courses?
message_2:
To determine the number of ways a student can choose 3 elective courses out of 6, we can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of elective courses (6 in this case), k is the number of courses the student needs to choose (3 in this case), and ! denotes the factorial function (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!(6-3)!)

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!3!)

C(6, 3) = (6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(3 × 2 × 1))

C(6, 3) = (720) / (6 × 6)

C(6, 3) = 720 / 36

C(6, 3) = 20

So, there are 20 different ways a student can choose 3 elective courses out of the 6 offered.
